It was bound to happen, but it's still big news. Chrysler has been bought by private equity firm Cerberus for a measly $7.4 billion, which is $30 billion(!) less than what Daimler paid for it during the late 90's. 
 
 Cerberus also owns a controlling stake in GMAC and is in talks to buy Delphi, so maybe they're planning on actually trying to make the company profitable again. I doubt it though, but you never know.
 Personally I'd split up Chrysler and sell the parts individually for a profit. IMO Chrysler is beyond hope and it should be put out of it's misery.

Would the new company have to honor all the old labour contracts?

 The UAW contracts expire in September, so new labor contracts will have to be negotiated, but the older agreements (heathcare etc.) still stand. So basically Chrysler will still be burdened by the old legacy costs. These legacy costs total about $18 billion.
 
 What really funny is that if you look at the specifics of this buyout, Daimler is actually not receiving a single penny from Cerberus. That's because most of the money is used as Cerberus' capital infusion into the car business and when all the bookkeeping is done, Daimler will actually have a net cash outflow of around $700 million.
 
 So basically Daimler is paying $700 million to get rid of Chrysler. If the laws would have allowed it, Daimler would have given away Chrysler for free to any bum on the street. :p
